description: The base solvent. Pure and safe at 100% concentration.
Promotes hair growth and prevents greying. Safe botanical.
Natural surfactant/cleanser. Gentle alternative to chemical soaps.
Conditions hair and treats dandruff. Safe edible herb.
Natural dye and conditioner. Rare allergic reactions possible.
Rich in Vitamin E. Excellent emollient for hair health.
Soothing agent. Reduces scalp irritation.
The 'King of Herbs' for hair growth. Highly safe.
High cleansing power but irritating. Best used at <15% in rinse-off products.
Ethoxylated surfactant. Risk of 1,4-Dioxane (carcinogen) trace contamination; safe if purified.
Mild foam booster. Can cause reactions due to manufacturing impurities (amidoamines).
Preservative. Safe up to 0.4% (single) or 0.8% (mixture) in the EU.
Linked to hormone mimicry. EU limit is 0.14% for the sum of propyl- and butylparabens.
Known human carcinogen. Banned in EU cosmetics; restricted release limit is 10ppm.
Powerful sensitizer. Restricted to 0.0015% in rinse-off products only.
Always used with MIT. Highly allergenic; prohibited in leave-on products.
Silicone oil for shine. Environmental build-up is the primary concern.
Exfoliant. Max 0.5% as preservative; max 2.0% in rinse-off hair products.
Botanical antioxidant. Safe for topical use at high concentrations.
Cationic conditioner from guar gum. Helps detangle hair without heavy buildup.
Synthetic fragrance. Banned due to reproductive toxicity (Endocrine Score 10).
Chelating agent. Prevents soap scum. Environmentally persistent (hard to break down).
Food-grade preservative. Max 0.5% in cosmetics; safe in standard concentrations.
Citrus scent. Must be labeled if >0.01% in rinse-off products.
Lavender scent. Can oxidize into a more potent allergen upon air exposure.
Anti-dandruff. Banned in EU (2022) due to reproductive toxicity and aquatic harm.
Pearlizing agent. Derived from stearic acid; safe and non-irritating.
Gentle coconut-based surfactant. Preferred for sensitive skin soaps.
White pigment. Risk when inhaled; safe in rinse-off soaps.
Global preservative. Max concentration 1% in the EU. Mildly irritating to eyes.
Humectant. Draws moisture into hair/skin. Completely safe at any concentration.
pH adjuster. Safe, but can cause mild stinging at high concentrations.
Used to thicken SLES-based shampoos. Can be drying at very high amounts.
Strengthens hair shaft. Safe and highly beneficial for scalp health.
Antistatic agent. Contains traces of Acrylamide (restricted to 0.1ppm).
Ethanolamine derivative. Max secondary amine content must be <0.5%.
Fragrance/Preservative. Max 1.0% in rinse-off; labeled as allergen if >0.01%.
Natural fatty acid used to harden bar soaps. Generally very safe.
Used in saponification. Scores 8 for potential skin burns if not fully reacted.
Synthetic polymer for gel texture. Microplastic concerns are under review in EU.
Cooling agent. Can be irritating to eyes and mucous membranes.
Essential oil. Known for scalp stimulation; safe if diluted.
Soothing extract. Scores 1 for carcinogenicity if aloin (latex) is present.
Fatty alcohol (non-drying). Used as a thickener and emollient.
Mild preservative. Used up to 0.6% in the EU; effective against mold.
Antibacterial. Banned by FDA/EU in hand soaps due to hormone disruption.
Conditioning agent. Irritating to eyes; toxic to aquatic life (Score 9).
Synthetic fragrance banned due to reproductive toxicity and being a potent endocrine disruptor.
Antibacterial agent banned by FDA and EU in consumer soaps due to hormone disruption and aquatic toxicity.
Known human carcinogen. Prohibited for use as a preservative in cosmetics; highly sensitizing.
A formaldehyde-releaser. Banned because it slowly releases carcinogenic formaldehyde into the product.
Paraben variant with the strongest endocrine-disrupting potential. Prohibited in global markets.
Preservative banned due to hormone mimicry and lack of safety data for long-term exposure.
Plasticizer often used in fragrances. Banned for reproductive toxicity (linked to birth defects).
Former anti-dandruff active. Banned due to reprotoxic classification and extreme aquatic lethality.
Antibacterial chemical prohibited in bar soaps due to persistent environmental harm and hormone interference.
A UV stabilizer banned due to thyroid hormone disruption and environmental persistence.
Neurotoxic heavy metal. Though mostly in skin lighteners, it is prohibited in all soap/shampoo formulations.
Fragrance molecule with an extremely high rate of skin sensitization and contact allergy.
A 'forever chemical' (PFAS) banned due to extreme environmental persistence and links to cancer.
Known human carcinogen. Banned in EU cosmetics; restricted to very low levels in US dandruff shampoos.
Potent neurotoxin once used as a germicide in soaps. Now universally prohibited.
Ultra-mild natural surfactant derived from coconut and fruit sugar. Safe for sensitive skin.
Binder and stabilizer. High molecular weight PEG; generally safe but check for impurities.
Antimicrobial essential oil. Great for dandruff but can be sensitizing if oxidized.
AHA exfoliant and pH adjuster. Enhances hair strength and moisture.
Synthetic yellow dye. Known to cause allergic reactions in some people (azo dye).
Synthetic red dye. Generally considered safe but can be an irritant.
Potent conditioning agent. Toxic to aquatic life. EU limit: 3.0% in rinse-off hair products.
Formaldehyde releaser found in Sunsilk/Tresemme. High risk of cancer and skin allergy.
Found in Head & Shoulders. Formally banned in EU (2022) due to reprotoxic classification.
Found in Oriflame. Can release Nitrosamines (carcinogens). Restricted to 0.1% in the EU.
Antioxidant in Pears. Suspected endocrine disruptor. Safe only at low concentrations (<0.8%).
Found in Elizavecca. Antistatic agent. EU limit: 2.5% for rinse-off hair products.
Found in Suave. Synthetic surfactant similar to SLES. Risk of 1,4-dioxane traces.
Synthetic dye in Clairol. Prohibited in products applied to mucous membranes.
Found in Vatika/Patanjali. Natural dye. Safe, but pure Lawsonia must be free of PPD.
Found in Patanjali. Ayurvedic herb for hair growth. Excellent safety profile.
Found in Redken. Antioxidant. Can cause severe allergic reactions in rare cases.
Found in Pears. Derived from pine resin. Known contact allergen for sensitive skin.
Found in Elizavecca. Banned in EU wash-off products >0.1% due to environmental accumulation.
Conditioning agent and preservative booster. Milder alternative to parabens.
Surfactant used to emulsify silicones. Environmentally harmful if not properly treated.
Drying alcohol. Used as a solvent. Can strip natural oils if high in the ingredient list.
Modified silicone that sticks to damaged hair. Harder to wash out, leading to buildup.
Natural soapnut extract. Contains saponins for natural cleansing.
Traditional Indian herb for hair cleansing. Very safe.
Found in Redken. Silicone replacement. Can cause eye irritation; toxic to fish.
Fatty alcohol used as an emollient and stabilizer. Not drying; safe for skin.
Silicone. Restricted in wash-off products (>0.1%) in EU due to environmental accumulation.
Moisturizing and soothing agent. Very safe.
Generic term for undefined scent chemicals. High risk of allergy and potential phthalates.
Antioxidant. Generally safe, though rarely causes contact dermatitis.
Natural colorant derived from sugar. Safe.
Solvent and humectant. Very low irritation potential.
Indian Curry Leaf. Rich in beta-carotene and proteins. Promotes hair growth.
Black seed extract. Antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory.
Powerhouse antioxidant. strengthens hair roots and prevents greying.
Natural conditioner. Promotes hair growth and prevents dandruff.
Cooling agent. Soothes scalp irritation.
Natural astringent. Cleanses scalp and fights dandruff. Can be drying.
Rich in protein and nicotinic acid. Fights hair fall and dandruff.
Potent antimicrobial and antifungal. Excellent for dandruff.
Jyotishmati oil. Nootropic herb often used in hair oils.
Ayurvedic herb. Cools the scalp and strengthens hair follicles.
Blood purifier herb. Promotes scalp health and color.
Vitamin B3. Improves scalp barrier function and reduces inflammation.
Humectant. Holds 1000x its weight in water. Hydrates scalp.
AHA exfoliant. Removes dead skin cells from scalp. Can be irritating.
Common preservative. Generally safe, but can form benzene if mixed with Vitamin C.
Mild preservative often used with Sodium Benzoate.
Strong preservative. High risk of contact dermatitis. Banned in leave-on products.
Preservative. Very common allergen. Banned in leave-on products in EU.
Saponified palm oil. Basic soap surfactant.
Chelating agent. Stabilizes soap. Poorly biodegradable.
Synthetic blue dye. Linked to some allergic reactions.
Synthetic red dye. Generally safe.
Cationic polymer. Conditions hair but can build up.
BHA exfoliant. Good for dandruff. Not safe for children under 3.
Natural fat from Shea tree. Excellent moisturizer.
Strong surfactant. Cleaning agent. Can be very drying and irritating to skin.
EU Limit: 3% in rinse-off hair products. Allergies: Can cause contact dermatitis and severe eye irritation if it exceeds safe levels.
EU Limit: 0.6%. A formaldehyde releaser. Allergies: Common cause of 'cosmetic dermatitis,' redness, and itchy rashes due to formaldehyde sensitivity.
Banned in EU (2022). US/India Limit: 1% for shampoos. Allergies: May cause stinging or localized skin peeling in sensitive users.
Global Limit: 1.0%. Allergies: Linked to eczema and life-threatening allergic reactions (anaphylaxis) in infants; can cause 'burning' sensation on broken skin.
EU Limit: 0.5% (preservative) or 2.0% (rinse-off). Allergies: Can cause 'aspirin-like' allergic reactions, hives, and extreme dryness.
EU Limit: 0.0015% (rinse-off only). Allergies: Named 'Allergen of the Year' due to high rates of severe blistering and painful skin swelling.
Safe up to 50% in formulations. Allergies: Causes scalp itchiness and 'tight skin' feeling; potential 1,4-dioxane contamination risk.
Safe Limit: 0.8%. Allergies: Rare but can trigger chronic hives (urticaria) and eye irritation.
Common fragrance. Must be listed if >0.01% in rinse-off. Allergies: Oxidizes on the shelf to become a potent sensitizer, causing redness and small bumps.
Usually used at 5-10%. Allergies: A leading cause of eyelid dermatitis and scalp rashes due to amidoamine impurities.
EU Limit: 0.1% in rinse-off (2026). Allergies: Low skin allergy risk but highly hazardous to the environment and aquatic life.
Max Limit: 1.0%. Allergies: Can cause 'contact urticaria' (immediate swelling) and intense itching in sensitive individuals.
pH adjuster. Limit: Up to pH 11. Allergies: Not a typical allergen, but causes severe chemical burns and scalp irritation if the product pH is unbalanced.
Limit: 0.1%. Allergies: Releases small amounts of formaldehyde; known for causing weeping eczema and painful skin inflammation.
Limit: Varies by component. Allergies: The #1 cause of cosmetic allergies; can trigger asthma, migraines, and widespread dermatitis.
Limit: 0.4%. Allergies: Generally low, but can cause 'delayed' allergic reactions where the rash appears 12-24 hours after use.
Limit: 2.5% in hair products. Allergies: High concentrations cause skin sensitisation and can lead to hair follicle inflammation.
Safe up to 50%. Allergies: Common cause of 'hives' and can worsen existing skin conditions like Rosacea or Psoriasis.
Safe up to 1%. Allergies: Very rare, making it a safe alternative for people with sensitive scalps.
Limit: 10%. Allergies: Can contain trace nitrosamines (carcinogens); causes mild redness and scalp dryness.
Banned in EU (2022). Allergies: Potent allergen and endocrine disruptor linked to fertility issues; causes severe skin rashes.
pH adjuster. No strict limit. Allergies: Rarely causes true allergy, but leads to 'stinging' in eyes and on sensitive skin if the product is too acidic.
Safe up to 2%. Allergies: Very low, but it increases skin permeability, allowing other allergens to sink deeper into the skin.
Limit: 2-5%. Allergies: Can cause eye irritation and localized skin inflammation; toxic to aquatic life.
No specific limit. Allergies: Strips natural oils leading to 'Contact Irritant Dermatitis' rather than a true allergy; extremely drying.
Label required >0.01%. Allergies: Common jasmine-scented allergen; leads to red, scaly patches behind the ears and on the neck.
Thickener. No limit. Allergies: Not an allergen, but very high levels can cause 'osmotic stress' leading to a dry, itchy scalp.
Pearlizing agent. No limit. Allergies: Extremely rare; one of the safest ingredients for sensitive skin in shampoos.
Limit: 2%. Allergies: Very rare; provides a protective film on hair which can sometimes lead to minor scalp buildup.
No limit. Allergies: None known; a very safe sugar-based humectant for all skin types.
Limit: 1-15%. Allergies: The primary cause of 'shampoo-induced' scalp irritation and can trigger mouth ulcers if in toothpaste.
Limit: Up to 10%. Allergies: Safe, but high concentrations can cause 'flushing' (temporary redness) due to blood vessel dilation.
Limit: 4% (consumer) or 10% (professional). Allergies: Increases sun sensitivity significantly; can cause chemical burns if left on too long.
Limit: 0.3%. Allergies: High risk of severe allergic contact dermatitis and rare cases of life-threatening anaphylaxis.
Safe up to 1%. Allergies: Oxidized oil is a major sensitizer; causes redness, blistering, and peeling on the scalp.
Thickener. Limit: 1-2%. Allergies: Extremely rare; one of the safest gelling agents available.
Safe up to 5%. Allergies: None; highly soothing and often used to treat skin irritation caused by other chemicals.
Limit: 10%. Allergies: May cause minor skin and eye irritation but is not considered a potent sensitizer.
Safe up to 5%. Allergies: Minimal; it stays on the hair shaft rather than the skin, reducing allergy risk.
Limit: 5%. Allergies: Surprisingly, it is a common allergen in lip and scalp products, leading to itchy, red patches.
Ethoxylated surfactant. May contain trace amounts of 1,4-dioxane, a potential carcinogen.
Mild biodegradable surfactant. Enhances foam and feel. Generally safe and non-irritating.
Natural emulsifier and emollient. Mimics skin's natural oils. Very safe.
Lightweight emollient. Provides a dry, non-greasy feel. Safe alternative to silicones.
Fatty alcohol used as a thickener and emollient. Can be mildly irritating in high concentrations.
Preservative and pH adjuster. Max 0.5% in acid products. Can be irritating and sensitizing.
Natural honey. Excellent humectant and antibacterial. Safe for all skin types.
Skimmed milk powder. Proteins condition skin and hair. Safe, unless allergic to dairy.
pH buffer and antioxidant aid. Completely safe.
Pure Vitamin E. Potent antioxidant. Prevents oil oxidation. Safe.
Emulsifier derived from palm oil. Skin conditioning agent. Safe.
Natural phospholipid from soy or egg. Restores skin barrier. Safe.
Synthetic yellow dye. Banned in foods in some countries (US, Japan) but allowed in cosmetics. Potential allergen.
Synthetic red dye. FDA restricted use to externally applied drugs and cosmetics (no eye area).
Silicone. Restricted in rinse-off products in EU due to environmental toxicity. Safe for human skin but bad for aquatic life.
Pro-Vitamin B5. Soothes scalp and strengthens hair. Very safe.
Dogwood fruit extract. Antioxidant and skin conditioner.
Chinese Foxglove root. Traditional herbal extract for hair conditioning.
Wild Yam extract. Skin conditioning agent.
Water Plantain tuber extract. Used in traditional medicine; conditions skin.
Peony root extract. Anti-inflammatory and antioxidant.
Mushroom extract. Soothing and antioxidant properties.
Skin-identical lipid. Restores protective barrier and locks in moisture. Excellent for damaged hair.
Silk protein. Adds shine and smooths hair cuticle.
Animal-derived protein. Increases hair elasticity and moisture.
Hair's natural protein. Repairs damage and strengthens hair structure.
Protein thickener. Forms a film on hair causing shine.
Oat extract. Soothes itchy scalps and reduces inflammation.
Solvent and preservative booster. Generally non-irritating.
Plant protein. Penetrates hair shaft to strengthen. Caution for gluten allergy.
Plant protein. Conditions and antistatic.
Soy protein. Improves hair texture and manageability.
Preservative. Limit 1%. Can cause irritation.

names: Daucus Carota Sativa (Carrot) Root Ext ract
description: Carrot extract. Rich in beta-carotene and vitamins.
Broccoli extract. Antioxidant-rich skin conditioner.
Celery extract. Can be phototoxic (furocoumarins) in large amounts but safe in small concentrations.

names: Brassica Oleracea Ca pitata (Cabbage) Leaf Extract
description: Cabbage leaf extract. Anti-inflammatory properties.
Rice extract. Conditions hair and skin.
Turnip leaf extract. Vitamin-rich conditioner.
Tomato extract. Antioxidant (Uycopene).
Simple alcohol. Antimicrobial and solvent. Can be drying and irritating to the skin barrier in high concentrations.
Curry leaf powder. Rich in antioxidants and beta-carotene. Promotes hair health and prevents graying.
Neem leaf powder. Powerful antibacterial and antifungal. Treats dandruff and scalp infections.
Centella Asiatica (Gotu Kola). Soothes scalp inflammation and stimulates hair growth.
Ratanjot root powder. Natural colorant and conditioner. Promotes hair growth.
Charila (Stone Flower). Traditional Ayurvedic ingredient used for skin and hair health.
Jatamansi rhizome powder. Calming herb that promotes hair growth and darkens hair.
Banyan tree aerial root powder. Traditional remedy for hair fall and scalp issues.
Sesame seed oil. Nourishing oil rich in fatty acids and antioxidants.
Coconut fruit oil. Deeply penetrating moisturizer. Prevents protein loss in hair.
Coconut milk. Rich in proteins and fats for conditioning.
Castor seed oil. Thick, viscous oil rich in ricinoleic acid. Promotes hair thickness.
Rosehip fruit oil. High in Vitamin A and C. Regenerates skin and scalp health.
Devdaru (Cedar) stem oil. Antiseptic and anti-inflammatory. Good for dandruff.
Melaleuca Leucadendron (Tea Tree/Cajeput) leaf oil. Strong antimicrobial. Can be irritating to sensitive skin.
Sodium salt of stearic acid. Common soap thickener and hardener. Generally safe, but high pH in soaps can dry skin.
Sodium salt of palm kernel oil. Cleansing agent in soaps. Safe for skin, but sustainability (palm oil) is a concern.
Polyethylene Glycol humectant. May be contaminated with 1,4-dioxane. Do not use on broken skin.
Fragrance mix. #1 allergen in skincare. Can trigger dermatitis and headaches.
Preservative and antioxidant. Can cause severe allergic reactions in asthmatics (sulfite allergy).
Chelating agent. Safe, but increases skin permeability to other potentially harmful ingredients.
Synthetic red pigment. Allowed in rinse-off products. Generally low risk.
Fragrance ingredient and preservative. Known skin irritant and toxic to aquatic life. EU 26 Alergen.
Fragrance and UV absorber. Suspected endocrine disruptor. Strong sensitizer. EU 26 Allergen.
Cinnamon scent. One of the most potent contact allergens in cosmetics. Causes rashes easily.
Clove scent. Potent allergen. Can cause contact dermatitis and stomatitis.
Emollient and surfactant. Generally safe conditioning agent for hair.
Buffering agent and preservative. Generally safe and non-irritating.
Thickener and texturizer. Natural mineral salt. Very safe.
Preservative stabilizer. Often found with Methylchloroisothiazolinone. Can be irritating to skin.
Chelating agent. Increases stability of products. Enhances absorption of other ingredients.
Rose/citrus scent. Common allergen. Must be declared on labels in EU.
Rose-like scent. Common sensitizer. Can cause dermatitis in sensitive individuals.
Biosurfactant. Eco-friendly cleansing agent. Generally mild.
Class of preservatives. Some are potential endocrine disruptors. Often avoided in 'clean' beauty.
Egg white protein. Tightens skin and controls oil.
Seaweed/Algae extract. Thickener. Can be comodogenic (pore-clogging) for some.
Preservative. Found naturally in berries. Can irritate sensitive eyes/skin.
Natural skin lightener (contains Arbutin). Brightens complexion.
Derived from brown algae. Thickener and water binder.
Natural cleansing agents found in plants. Gentle alternative to sulfates.
Mineral-rich salt. Exfoliates and improves skin barrier function.
Essential mineral. Restores skin barrier and regulates cell turnover.
Rich in fatty acids and Vitamins A, D, E. Deeply moisturizing.
Liquid Gold. High in Vitamin E. Moisturizes and softens hair/skin.
Potent antioxidant. Brightens skin and boosts collagen. High concentrations may sting.
Vasoconstrictor. Reduces puffiness and stimulates hair roots.
Gold standard anti-aging. Increases cell turnover. Can cause redness, peeling, and sun sensitivity.
Vine extract. Powerful antioxidant (Resveratrol). Anti-aging.
Patented anti-aging molecule. Boosts skin hydration and firmness.
Broken down collagen. Easier absorption. Signals skin to repair itself.
Essential mineral. Soothes inflammation and improves barrier repair.
Absorbent. Draws out impurities and oil from pores. deeply cleansing.
Soothing and moisturizing. Fragrance can be sensitizing to some.
Rich in vitamins and minerals. Brightens and revitalizes skin.
Citrus extract. High Vitamin C. Brightening but potential photo-sensitizer.
Rich emollient fat. Deeply hydrating but highly comedogenic (pore-clogging).
Plant-derived ceramide. Restores barrier and hydration.
Astringent and antiseptic. Good for oily skin/scalp.
Cooling and stimulating. Can irritate sensitive skin (Menthol).
Antioxidant. Stimulates microcirculation.
Soothing and hydrating. Mild astringent. Fragrance can be sensitizing.
Rich in polysaccharides. Hydrating and film-forming.
Oil-absorbing mineral. Cleanses pores. Can be drying.
Rich in tannins and antioxidants. Firming and soothing.
Antiseptic and refreshing. Potent sensitizer if oxidized or used in high amounts.
Nutrient-rich sap. Hydrating and soothing.
High Vitamin C and E. Brightening and exfoliating (enzymatic).
Lightweight oil. High in linoleic acid. Good for acne-prone skin.
Milder form of Retinol. Convertible to active Vitamin A in skin. Anti-aging.
Cell-communicating ingredient. Antibacterial and anti-inflammatory. Anti-aging.
Calming. Fragrance allergen (Linalool). Cytotoxic to skin cells in high concentrations.
Peptide complex. Stimulates collagen and improves skin texture.
Structural protein. Strengthens hair and nails.
Liquid wax similar to skin sebum. Balances oil production. Stable and safe.
Plant-derived anti-aging complex. volumizing.
Energizing antioxidant. Improves circulation and skin tone.
Antioxidant flower extract. Brightening and soothing.
Synthetic buffering agent. Promotes enzymatic exfoliation. Can be sensitizing.
Antioxidant complex derived from Bitter Orange. Protecs against UV damage.
Low molecular weight Hyaluronic Acid. Penetrates deeper for hydration.
Specific ceramide type. Reinforces skin barrier structure.
Stabilized Vitamin C derivative. Brightening and antioxidant. Gentler than pure Vitamin C.
Gentle exfoliant. Activates enzymes in the skin.
Strong surfactant. Cleanses well but can be harsh and drying compared to Sodium Laureth Sulfate.
Rich biological oil. High in antioxidants. Safe for skin, but environmental concerns (deforestation).
Fatty alcohol. Emollient and solvent. Conditioning agent.
Natural humectant found in skin. Binds water to cells. Very safe.
Mild surfactant derived from coconut fatty acids and amino acids.
Cleansing agent. Enhances foam. Generally sufficient safety profile.
Amino acid. Essential for hair growth and scalp health. Increases circulation.
Hair strengthening complex. Penetrates shaft to increase moisture and elasticity.
Surfactant from coconut oil. Mild but potential allergen (impurities).
pH adjuster. Helps maintain acid mantle of scalp.
Emulsifier and surfactant. Helps mix oils and water.
Vitamin B6. Regulates oil production. Good for oily scalp/skin.
Very mild plant-derived surfactant. Ideal for sensitive skin.
Copper peptide. Promotes wound healing and collagen production.
Solvent and viscosity agent. Can be irritating to eyes.
thickener. PEG derivative (contamination risk).
Emulsifier and emollient. Leaves skin soft.
Chelating agent. Stabilizes formula.
Conditioning polymer. Anti-static and film-forming.
Bilberry extract. Potent antioxidant (Anthocyanins). Soothing.
Zinc form. Sebum regulating and anti-acne.
Natural wax. Protective barrier. Can be heavy/comedogenic.
Surfactant structures. Trap dirt and oil gently.
Gentle chemical exfoliants. Hydrating. Good for sensitive skin.
Beneficial bacteria derivatives. Support skin microbiome.
Sea Buckthorn. High in Omegas (3, 6, 9, 7) and Vitamins. Healing.
Immune-boosting herb. Soothing and anti-inflammatory.
Detoxifying herb. Anti-fungal and sebum regulating.
Sage extract. Antibacterial and astringent. Darkens gray hair naturally.
Mild surfactant from Babassu oil. Antistatic.
Baby foam. Very mild surfactant. Leaves skin soft.
Mild sulphate-free surfactant. Excellent foam.
Large molecule surfactant. Cannot penetrate skin, so very low irritation.
Dormin. Slows down cell proliferation (hair growth inhibitor) or protects skin cells.
Lemon scent component. Strong allergen. EU 26 Allergen.
Emulsifier. Solubilizes oils in water. PEG-derivative.
Antistatic and conditioning agent.
Humectant and preservative booster. Gentle antimicrobial.
Emollient. Silicone alternative. Adds shine.
Bio-fermented mineral complex. Enhances mineral absorption and efficacy.
Wheat germ protein. Nutritious and conditioning. Caution for gluten allergy.
Synthetic oil. Good emollient but highly comedogenic (clogs pores).
Colloidal Oatmeal. Soothes eczema and irritation.
Surfactant and emulsifier. Stabilizes emulsions.
Flavoring agent and preservative. Masking agent.
Light, non-comedogenic oil. High in linoleic acid. Repairs barrier.
Sheep wool wax. Excellent occlusive moisturizer. Common allergen.
Rapeseed oil. Rich in lipids. Moisturizing.
Opacifying agent. Gives products a pearlescent look.
Buffering agent against pH changes. Corrosion inhibitor.
Anti-static and hair conditioner derived from Castor Oil.
Phospholipid complex. Gentle cleansing and conditioning.
Foam booster and viscosity agent.
Synthetic violet dye. Used in optical brighteners/purple shampoos.
